message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of Mallory-Weiss syndrome, which is characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction typically caused by forceful vomiting. Dilated veins in the esophageal submucosa are seen in esophageal varices, but the patient does not have risk factors for it. Rupture of the distal esophagus and friable mass in the distal esophagus are consistent with Boerhaave syndrome and esophageal cancer, respectively, but these are less likely given the patient's history and presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Mallory-Weiss tear, which is mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction. Options A, B, and D are all indicative of more severe conditions and are unlikely findings given the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Mallory-Weiss syndrome, which often presents as mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction after forceful vomiting. Dilated veins in the esophageal submucosa relates to esophageal varices, rupture of the distal esophagus relates to Boerhaave syndrome, and a friable mass in the distal esophagus relates to esophageal cancer, all of which are less likely causes given this patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest Mallory-Weiss syndrome, which is characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction caused by forceful vomiting. Dilated veins in the esophageal submucosa indicate esophageal varices, which are typically associated with liver cirrhosis. Rupture of the distal esophagus is seen in Boerhaave syndrome, which typically presents with severe chest pain, fever, and shock. There is no indication of a friable mass in the distal esophagus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest Mallory-Weiss syndrome, which is characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction. Dilated veins in the esophageal submucosa suggest esophageal varices, which more commonly occur in patients with liver disease. Rupture of the distal esophagus is seen in Boerhaave syndrome, which is associated with forceful vomiting but is less common. There is no mention of a friable mass in the distal esophagus in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and calluses on the dorsal aspect of her right hand indicate bulimia nervosa. Forceful vomiting can lead to mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction, also known as Mallory-Weiss syndrome. Dilated veins in the esophageal submucosa, rupture of the distal esophagus, and a friable mass in the distal esophagus are all possible complications of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease, but are unlikely given the patient’s acute presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest that the most likely diagnosis is Mallory-Weiss syndrome, which is a mucosal laceration at the gastroesophageal junction caused by forceful vomiting. Dilated veins in the esophageal submucosa suggest esophageal varices; ruptured distal esophagus suggests Boerhaave syndrome; friable mass in the distal esophagus suggests esophageal cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest Mallory-Weiss syndrome, which is caused by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction due to forceful vomiting. Dilated veins in the esophageal submucosa are seen in esophageal varices, which are usually associated with liver disease. The rupture of the distal esophagus is seen in Boerhaave syndrome, which is a medical emergency. A friable mass in the distal esophagus could indicate esophageal cancer, but there is no evidence of that in the question stem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with chest and epigastric pain after vomiting, forceful bloody emesis, dental enamel erosion, and calluses indicating bulimia nervosa, a condition where patients induce vomiting. Among the given options, mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction, also known as Mallory-Weiss syndrome, is the most likely finding due to the repeated vomiting. Dilated veins in the esophageal submucosa, or varices, are seen in patients with chronic liver disease. Rupture of the distal esophagus or Boerhaave syndrome is a medical emergency but is not associated with bulimia nervosa. A friable mass in the distal esophagus suggests malignancy, which is unlikely in a 22-year-old patient with a recent onset of symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest that the patient has a Mallory-Weiss tear, characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction caused by prolonged or forceful vomiting. Dilated veins in the esophageal submucosa are seen in esophageal varices, which are associated with chronic liver disease. Rupture of the distal esophagus is seen in Boerhaave syndrome, which is typically associated with chest pain and subcutaneous emphysema. There is no information to suggest a friable mass in the distal esophagus.
